Laeli: the addition of the praenomen, not usual in familiar conversation, gives formality to the address: cf. roo. — animum adverti: animum aduertere and animadvertere (cf. 27) differ very little in use and not at all in sense. Animum advertere is said to be necessary when the construction ad aliquid (to turn the mind to something) follows. — cum...amicissimi: the⁴natural order would have been viri cum summi tum amicissimi. A word however which (liltevirr' here) stands in the same relation towards two other words or phrases, is often placed thus between the two. The old grammarians called this usage coniuncta,- cf. Cornificius Ad Heren- nium 4, 38 coniunctio cst cum imerposiriane verbi et superiores orationis partes comprehenduntur et inferiores, hoc modo: Formae dignitas aut morbo deflorescit aut vetustate.
